channel.title: NYT > Arts

item.title: In ‘Memory of a Killer,’ Patrick Dempsey Takes the Wheel
item.description: The actor has spent a decade dismantling his McDreamy persona from “Grey’s Anatomy.” He stars as an assassin in a new Fox thriller.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski and Nathan Cyprys
item.media:credit: Nathan Cyprys for The New York Times

item.title: Art Stars Remember the Legendary Steward Marian Goodman
item.description: William Kentridge, Steve McQueen, Julie Mehretu, Tacita Dean and other leading figures celebrate a ferocious dealer and champion who changed their lives.
item.dc:creator: Will Heinrich
item.category: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
item.media:description: Marian Goodman in her gallery on West 57th Street in 2016 with a painting by Julie Mehretu. “Everyone felt deeply respected by her, all of the artists that worked with her,” Mehretu said. “That was a very unique dynamic.”

item.title: Denyce Graves Says Goodbye to the Opera Stage After 40 Years
item.description: Graves, who gave her last performance on Saturday at the Met, talks about “Carmen,” the doctor who told her she would never sing again and the Kennedy Center.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The mezzo-soprano Denyce Graves persevered through health challenges to become one of opera’s top singers.

item.title: For This Influencer, Rejection Is the New Perfection
item.description: One young woman’s mission of being rejected 1,000 times has inspired other social media users to seek out no’s.
item.dc:creator: Megan Farokhmanesh

item.title: The Royal Winnipeg Ballet, on the (Bumpy) Road to Reconciliation
item.description: The Indigenous choreographer Cameron Fraser-Monroe is taking his ballet on tour, “back to the place where the story was kept.”
item.dc:creator: Martha Schabas
item.media:credit: Jaida Grey Eagle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cameron Fraser-Monroe’s ballet “T’el” was inspired by a legend his elders told him as a boy.

item.title: Memory and Speech Are Their Everyday Struggles. Then They Get to Sing.
item.description: At the Singing Circle in Amsterdam, people with cognitive decline join together to lift their spirits and improve their lives.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times

item.title: Kanye West Apologizes for Antisemitic Behavior in Full-Page Wall Street Journal Ad
item.description: The artist formerly known as Kanye West, who first apologized in 2023 before taking it back, said a four-month manic episode in 2025 had led him to embrace swastikas and Hitler.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Matt Winkelmeyer/Getty Images For The Recording A
item.media:description: Ye at the Grammy Awards in Los Angeles in 2025.

item.title: Review: How ‘Data’ Channels the Shock of Right Now
item.description: In Matthew Libby’s play, a brilliant young computer programmer finds himself at the center of one of the most contentious issues of the moment: immigration.
item.dc:creator: Tim Teeman
item.media:credit: Rachel Papo for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Sophia Lillis, Karan Brar and Justin H. Min in “Data,” at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

item.title: ‘Bridgerton,’ Plus 5 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: This Regency-era drama is back for a fourth season, and the 2026 Grammy Awards will air.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:description: Luke Thompson and Yerin Ha in “Bridgerton.”

item.title: S.N.L. Recap: Teyana Taylor Hosts, the First Trump Awards and More
item.description: A covetous president grabbed up all the trophies on this week’s “Saturday Night Live” broadcast, hosted by Teyana Taylor, star of “One Battle After Another.”
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff

item.title: Geese Gives ‘Saturday Night Live’ Viewers Something to Talk About
item.description: The buzzy Brooklyn band brought its off-kilter aesthetic to network TV this weekend, with performances that were both confounding and audacious.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz

item.title: Luke Thompson Finally Takes the ‘Bridgerton’ Spotlight
item.description: As his character assumes the lead in a new season, Luke Thompson is bringing Shakespearean depth to one of the buzziest streaming shows of our time.
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Stanford and Kalpesh Lathigra
item.media:credit: Kalpesh Lathigra for The New York Times

item.title: Days Before His Suicide, Hemingway’s Hopeful Note to Sister Immaculata
item.description: In 1961, the author inscribed a book for the sister, a nurse who cared for him at the Mayo Clinic. Her copy of “The Old Man and the Sea” is being donated to the Nobel Museum.
item.dc:creator: John Rosengren
item.category: The Old Man and the Sea (Book)
item.media:description: Ernest Hemingway in Cuba in 1952.

item.title: ‘A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms’ Season 1 Episode 2 Recap: A Man Among Princes
item.description: A certain royal family known for dragons and blond hair arrives on the scene. One of our heroes, at least, seems appropriately wary.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.category: A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms (TV Program)
item.media:description: Dunk and Egg (Peter Claffey, left, and Dexter Sol Ansell) have notably different reactions when the Targaryens ride onto the scene.

item.title: Floyd Vivino, Throwback Comedian Known as Uncle Floyd, Dies at 74
item.description: His silly, vaudeville-style variety show was filled with his piano playing, skits, puppets and guest stars like Cyndi Lauper and Bon Jovi.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Mr. Vivino in 1984. He was sometimes compared to Soupy Sales, a slapstick comic who hosted a syndicated children’s program. Uncle Floyd’s silly absurdism also seemed to augur the arrival of Pee-wee Herman.

item.title: Marian Goodman, Eminent New York Art Dealer, Dies at 97
item.description: Although known for promoting German painters, she also sought out artists who shunned painting in favor of newer mediums, like photography and film.
item.dc:creator: Deborah Solomon
item.media:description: Marian Goodman in 2016 in her gallery in New York. She played a major role in bringing avant-garde European art to prominence in the 1980s.

item.title: Long-Lost Robert Burns Portrait Is on Display for Burns Night
item.description: The whereabouts of a painting of Robert Burns by Henry Raeburn was unknown for two centuries. Now, the work is on display in time for the annual Burns Night honoring the writer.
item.dc:creator: Precious Adesina
item.media:description: The rediscovered portrait of Burns by Raeburn, left, and a smaller portrait of the writer by Nasmyth.

item.title: Marc Shaiman, ‘Hairspray’ Composer, on Surviving Life in the Musical Trenches
item.description: Broadway, Hollywood and television have been kind to Marc Shaiman. But there’s a reason the subtitle of his new memoir is “Showbiz Stories From a Sore Winner.”
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green
item.category: Never Mind the Happy: Showbiz Stories from a Sore Winner (Book)
item.media:credit: Amy Lombard for The New York Times

item.title: Beatriz González, Who Chronicled Colombia’s Turmoil in Paint, Dies at 93
item.description: Often drawing from reproduced images or newspaper photos, she made work that quietly yet memorably critiqued her country’s social and political order.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Ms. González in 2016. Her father “taught me to look at the landscape, from the mountain ranges to the streams flowing from the Magdalena River,” she said, while her mother “helped to train my eye.”

item.title: Sophie Turner Swears By a Chaotic Spotify Playlist
item.description: “One minute it’s playing Ludovico Einaudi, and then the next minute it’s playing stuff from the ’60s or two days ago,” said the “Game of Thrones” actress.
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Shattuck

item.title: 6 Podcasts About Medicine and Health Care
item.description: These shows can help you navigate a time of soaring insurance costs, confusing policy changes and medical misinformation.
item.dc:creator: Emma Dibdin
item.category: This Podcast Will Kill You (Radio Program)

item.title: 9 Songs We’re Talking About This Week
item.description: Harry Styles has a new album (and mega-residency at Madison Square Garden) on the way, and Sienna Spiro’s tearful ballad is climbing the Hot 100.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles

item.title: Renée Fleming Won’t Perform at Kennedy Center Concerts
item.description: The soprano, who previously resigned as an artistic adviser, was scheduled to sing with the National Symphony Orchestra in May.
item.dc:creator: Jason M. Bailey
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: Renée Fleming was honored by the Kennedy Center in 2023.

item.title: John H. Beyer, 92, Dies; Architect Championed Historic Preservation
item.description: The last surviving founder of Beyer Blinder Belle, he helped safeguard New York City’s past even as developers raced to push the city into the future.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: 2026 Oscar Nominees: Surprises and Snubs
item.description: Kyle Buchanan, our awards season columnist, breaks down the Academy Award nominations for 2026.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan, Edward Vega and Laura Salaberry

item.title: For His Next Act, Darren Walker Is Heading to Hollywood
item.description: Anonymous Content, a production company whose top investor is Laurene Powell Jobs’s Emerson Collective, has named Darren Walker as president and chief executive.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Nate Langston Palmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Storytelling shapes culture, informs how we see ourselves and how we see the humanity in others,” Darren Walker said of his move to Anonymous Content.

item.title: South African Artist Sues Over Venice Biennale Snub
item.description: A panel recommended that Gabrielle Goliath represent South Africa at the event. But the culture minister rejected its suggestion.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: The artist Gabrielle Goliath, right, and the curator Ingrid Masondo want to represent South Africa at the 2026 Venice Biennale, but the country’s culture minister considers their planned exhibition inappropriate.

item.title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include lonely swordsmen, buddy cops, and a World War II German tank.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels
item.media:description: Ashton Chen in “Blade of Fury.”

item.title: Review: Thomas Adès and America at the New York Philharmonic
item.description: Thomas Adès led the New York Philharmonic in an expanded version of his “America: A Prophecy” that strikes notes of caution and consolation.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone

item.title: Documentary Oscar Nominees Resist Authority in Different Ways
item.description: Reflecting the power of nonfiction filmmaking, each contender involves subjects and even directors resisting authority in different ways.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Come See Me in the Good Light (Movie)

item.title: 6 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: 5 Takeaways From the HBO Documentary ‘Mel Brooks: The 99 Year Old Man!’
item.description: Judd Apatow, who co-directed, offered insights into the making of the two-part film, a loving portrait of a comedy giant who’s still sharp as ever.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik
item.category: Mel Brooks: The 99 Year Old Man! (TV Program)

item.title: Turning 4 Miles of Silk Into a Stunning Theater Spectacle
item.description: Miet Warlop’s work is visually breathtaking, but there are deep questions to ponder beneath the showy surfaces.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall and Ilvy Njiokiktjien

item.title: 7 Sports Documentaries to Stream Now
item.description: A beloved sports commentator, the W.N.B.A.’s leading scorer and the franchise known as America’s team go under the microscope.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.category: America's Team: The Gambler and His Cowboys (TV Program)

item.title: Broadway Shows Closing Soon: ‘Mamma Mia!,’ ‘Hell’s Kitchen’ and More
item.description: The curtain is about to come down on two jukebox musicals, a thriller by Tracy Letts, and other Broadway productions.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.media:credit: Richard Termine for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Jalynn Steele, Christine Sherrill and Carly Sakolove in “Mamma Mia!” The show’s run at the Winter Garden Theater concludes on Feb. 1.

item.title: Candi Staton Is a Survivor. At 85, She’s Also a Grammy Nominee.
item.description: The singer’s journey through gospel, soul, disco and Americana has been plagued by setbacks and struggles, but she has always found the path forward.
item.dc:creator: Garth Cartwright
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Candi Staton earned her first Grammy nomination in nearly 40 years for her latest album, “Back to My Roots.”

item.title: Immersive Historical Fiction Full of Rule Breakers and Rebels
item.description: The author Janie Chang recommends novels about people who push back against the expectations of their time.
item.dc:creator: Janie Chang

item.title: Seth Meyers Says Trump’s Deals Are as Strong as a Pinkie Swear
item.description: “At this point, it’s pretty clear world leaders make deals with Trump the way kids do on the playground,” Meyers said of the president on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2 Episode 3 Recap: Expect the Unexpected
item.description: The doctors are seeing a lot of rare cases on this Fourth of July. Not even the fireworks-related injuries have been straightforward.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:description: When Dr. Al-Hashimi (Sepideh Moafi) isn’t butting heads with Dr. Robby, she has excellent bedside manner.

item.title: James Bernard, a Founding Editor of a Hip-Hop ‘Bible,’ Dies at 58
item.description: One of the most influential voices of the seminal magazine The Source, he chronicled rap’s rise and its explosion into the cultural mainstream.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: The Cliburn, Known for Piano Competitions, Will Hold One for Conductors
item.description: The trailblazing conductor Marin Alsop will chair the jury for the inaugural Cliburn International Competition for Conductors in 2028.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The idea for the new competition came from Marin Alsop, the first woman to be the music director of a top-tier U.S. orchestra.

item.title: Fine Arts Panel, Remade by Trump, Indicates Support for His Ballroom Plan
item.description: The president has stacked a commission with allies as he has pushed to construct a 90,000-square-foot addition to the White House. A federal judge signaled he might block the project.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Zach Montague
item.media:description: A rendering of the proposed White House ballroom in the Oval Office last month.

item.title: Stream These 8 Titles Before They Leave Netflix in February
item.description: A couple of horror classics, a beloved sitcom and a great Paul Thomas Anderson film are among the gems leaving for U.S. subscribers next month.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey
item.media:credit: Melinda Sue Gordon/Metro Goldwyn Mayer Pictures
item.media:description: Cooper Hoffman, left, and Alana Haim, center, in the Paul Thomas Anderson film “Licorice Pizza.”

item.title: Where to Stream the 2026 Oscar Nominees: ‘Sinners,’ ‘One Battle After Another’ and More
item.description: Many of the top contenders can be watched at home. Here’s a guide to help you get a jump on the field.
item.dc:creator: Scott Tobias
item.category: If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)

item.title: Harry Styles Books 30 Dates for Madison Square Garden Residency
item.description: The pop star is returning with his fourth solo album on March 6. His Together, Together tour, which will hit seven cities, is scheduled to begin in May.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.category: Kiss All the Time. Disco, Occasionally. (Album)
item.media:description: Harry Styles onstage at Madison Square Garden in 2022. The pop star will return to the arena for 30 dates this year.

item.title: ‘Clika’ Review: Dreaming of the Stage
item.description: This film about a fieldworker trying to make it in music offers a Mexican American spin on underdog dreamer movies like “8 Mile.”
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: These Objects Will Draw You Out of the Cold
item.description: Among scores of artworks, these 9 light up the Winter Show at the Park Avenue Armory, featuring more than 70 international dealers.
item.dc:creator: Will Heinrich
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: These three-foot-long “slap shoes” were used by the 4’6” English vaudevillian Harry Relph, known as “Little Tich,” who could balance on the toes, on view at the Winter Show at the Park Avenue Armory.

item.title: Five Fronts in Trump’s Culture War
item.description: In the first year of his second term, President Trump has made sweeping efforts to influence the arts and media in America.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: During a White House dinner in October, President Trump showed models of a triumphal arch he is planning to build in Washington.

item.title: Oscar Snubs and Surprises: ‘Sinners’ Makes History, ‘Wicked’ Withers
item.description: Ariana Grande, Chase Infiniti and Paul Mescal were shut out, but voters made room for Delroy Lindo, Kate Hudson and “F1.”
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: A 67,800-Year-Old Handprint May Be the World’s Oldest Rock Art
item.description: “It was hiding in plain sight all this time,” one researcher said.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and Yan Zhuang

item.title: ‘Sinners’ Broke the Oscars Record These 3 Films Once Held
item.description: As categories evolved over time, the way to make academy history did, too. But for decades, no film topped 14 nods, until “Sinners” smashed the record.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam

item.title: The Exacting, Ephemeral Art of Ice Carving
item.description: A look inside a Queens studio where Buddhas, sneakers and swans are carved with reverence and the knowledge that beauty, like ice, is fleeting.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi and Erin Schaff

item.title: 2026 Oscar Nominations: See the Full List
item.description: The movies competing for the 98th Academy Awards. The ceremony will air on March 15.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez and Kellina Moore
item.category: Come See Me in the Good Light (Movie)
If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)
Little Amelie or the Character of Rain (Movie)

item.title: Oscar Nominations: ‘Sinners’ Breaks Record With 16
item.description: “One Battle After Another” was close behind with 13 nods. Acting nominees include Michael B. Jordan, Kate Hudson, Timothée Chalamet and Teyana Taylor.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
item.category: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

item.title: Jason Mantzoukas Makes It Weird
item.description: As TV’s go-to maniac, the actor has a flair for chaos that also functions as a kind of emotional armor. “I’m still very protective of the actual me,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.category: Percy Jackson and the Olympians (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Michael Tyrone Delaney for The New York Times
item.media:description: It may surprise fans to learn that offstage and off mic, Jason Mantzoukas is pleasantly normal.

item.title: When Jasper Johns Drew the Line
item.description: A new exhibition revisits a turning point in the career of the 95-year-old artist: the paintings that faced down death to find meaning in life.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago
item.media:credit: Jasper Johns/Licensed by VAGA at Artists Rights Society (ARS), NY; Janice Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Detail, Jasper Johns, “Between the Clock and the Bed,” 1981, at Gagosian. After painting targets and flags, he turned to a new kind of markmaking: crosshatch abstractions whose fidgety lines trace the artist’s earthly path from anxiety to acceptance of mortality.

item.title: A Public-Art Veteran Will Lead Creative Time
item.description: Jean Cooney, a former deputy director of the New York City public-art institution, is the organization’s next leader.
item.dc:creator: Hilarie M. Sheets

item.title: America Turns 250: A Guide to the Coming Festivities
item.description: Girl Scouts singing folk songs, a flag-waving party and a Times Square ball drop are among the planned Semiquincentennial celebrations.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Mercy’ Review: Chris Pratt Trapped in a Dystopian Future
item.description: Chris Pratt plays a man accused of killing his wife in this witless action-thriller where harsh justice is dispensed by artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘Return to Silent Hill’ Review: A Macabre Spectacle
item.description: This latest installment in the video game movie franchise looks like it’s meant to be played.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza
